title: Implement Compatibility-mode write-set spill + coordinator-only WAL append
close_reason: Obsolete: planning-phase spec updated; implementation work will be re-triaged later

title: Spec Evolution Viz: Next UX/Feature Pass
description: Follow-up work to make the spec-evolution visualization more powerful, intuitive, and shareable (desktop + mobile), while keeping everything static-site deployable (Cloudflare Pages) and offline-friendly.

title: Viz: Compare Two Arbitrary Commits (A/B)
description: Add a compare mode where users pick two commits (A and B) and see a rendered diff between reconstructed spec snapshots (Diff2Html), plus metrics (lines/tokens/lev). Should support keyboard + mobile-friendly selection.

title: Viz: Outlier Dashboard (Largest Deltas + Chart Annotations)
description:
Goal
- Make the most important moments obvious: a dashboard that surfaces commits (or time bins) with the largest changes (Δlines/Δtokens/Δlev, bucket-weighted), and annotates those points directly on the charts.

UX (Desktop)
- Outlier panel: Top-N list with metric selector and filters (bucket, time resolution, day/hour/15m/5m).
- Clicking an outlier jumps timeline + opens doc/diff at that commit; chart point pulses subtly.

UX (Mobile)
- Compact list inside sheet; tap-to-jump with a back affordance.

Implementation Notes
- Outlier scoring should be explainable and robust (median/MAD z-score preferred over mean/stddev).
- Support both per-commit and aggregated-bin outliers (wall-clock bins).
- Persist selection in URL state for sharing.

Acceptance Criteria
- Users can find "big changes" in under 5 seconds and jump to them reliably.

Testing
- Unit tests for robust outlier scoring + tie-breaking.
- E2E: select metric, open outlier, verify commit idx/hash + chart marker.

title: Outliers: Compute Robust Scores (MAD Z) + Top-K
description:
Implement explainable outlier detection:
- For each metric series (lines/tokens/lev and bucket-weighted variants), compute robust center/scale (median + MAD).
- Compute robust z-scores; rank top-K with stable tie-breaking (timestamp then hash).
- Support both per-commit series and aggregated time-bin series.
- Export an "evidence" object per outlier: value, median, MAD, z, and contributing buckets.

title: Outliers: UI Panel + Chart Point Annotations
description:
Build the outlier UX:
- Panel: metric dropdown, Top-N selector, filters (buckets, time resolution), and a clear "why this is an outlier" evidence drawer.
- Charts: annotate outlier points (small markers) + hover tooltip; clicking marker selects corresponding list item and jumps commit.
- Mobile: panel inside sheet; chart annotation remains visible but not cluttered.

title: Outliers: Unit Tests (Robust Scoring + Evidence)
description:
Unit tests:
- MAD z-score correctness on synthetic series with known median/MAD.
- Edge cases: MAD=0, short series, NaNs, identical points.
- Evidence object: ensure it includes value/median/MAD/z and sums for bucket-weighted series.

Diagnostics
- On failure, print the series, computed stats, and top-K list.

title: Outliers: E2E Tests (Panel + Chart Marker Jump)
description:
E2E scenarios:
- Select metric (lev), set Top-N=5, click #1 outlier -> commit selection changes and charts show marker.
- Click marker on chart -> outlier list selection changes and doc/diff updates.

Diagnostics
- Log chosen metric, outlier ids/hashes, and whether chart marker series is present.

title: Viz: Phase Map Overlay (Change Points + Regime Segments)
description:
Goal
- Turn the evolution into readable "phases": detect change points in the metric series (lev/tokens/lines and/or bucket-weighted), then overlay regime segments directly on the charts and timeline dock.

UX (Desktop)
- Toggle "Phase overlay": charts show softly tinted phase bands + labels (Phase 1..N). Hover shows segment stats (duration, mean, variance, top buckets).
- Clicking a phase band filters commit list + section summary to that segment.

UX (Mobile)
- Phase bands visible but subtle; phase details appear in a bottom sheet on tap.

Implementation Notes (Alien-Artifact Leaning)
- Use principled change-point detection (BOCPD with explicit hazard + likelihood model) and expose an evidence ledger per detected change (posterior mass / score).
- Prefer explainable segmentation over ad-hoc thresholds; allow selecting the driving metric.
- Cache computed phases in worker/localStorage by dataset hash.

Acceptance Criteria
- Phases feel stable and useful (not flickery); user can understand what changed and when.

Testing
- Unit tests using synthetic piecewise-stationary sequences; assert detected change points within tolerance.
- E2E tests: toggle phase overlay, tap a phase, verify filtering/jump behavior.

title: Phase Map: BOCPD Implementation + Evidence Ledger
description:
Implement / improve BOCPD in a way that's reliable and explainable:
- Choose likelihood model(s): e.g., Gaussian for normalized series, Poisson for count-like series.
- Explicit hazard function; expose "sensitivity" as an interpretable parameter.
- Output: change points + segments with posterior mass / confidence.
- Evidence ledger per change: top contributing metric movement, before/after means/vars, and any bucket-weight contribution if available.
- Run in worker; cache by dataset hash + metric + sensitivity.

title: Phase Map: Overlay Rendering + Phase Interactions
description:
Render phase segments into the main charts and timeline dock:
- Subtle tinted bands behind the line/stack chart; labels that don't clutter.
- Hover/tap reveals phase summary (duration, mean/var, top buckets).
- Clicking a phase filters commit list + outlier panel + section summary to that segment; toggle to clear filter.
- URL state stores selected phase id + metric used for segmentation.

title: Phase Map: Unit Tests (Synthetic Change-Point Sequences)
description:
Unit tests:
- Synthetic piecewise-stationary sequences (2-5 segments) with controlled noise; assert change points detected within an index tolerance.
- Edge cases: constant series, single spike, gradual drift.
- Evidence ledger invariants: posterior/confidence in [0,1], segments cover all indices with no gaps/overlaps.

Diagnostics
- On failure, print the series, detected cps, and per-cp evidence summary.

title: Phase Map: E2E Tests (Toggle + Phase Filter)
description:
E2E scenarios:
- Toggle phase overlay on/off; ensure chart renders without errors.
- Click/tap a phase band -> commit list and outlier list filter to that segment; clear filter restores full set.
- URL round-trip: copy permalink with phase selected; reload -> same phase is selected.

Diagnostics
- Log metric used, phase id, segment boundaries, and filtered commit count.

title: Viz: Commit-Time vs Wall-Clock Binning Toggle
description:
Goal
- Let users view the same evolution in two time coordinate systems:
  - Commit-time (index order): emphasizes sequence of edits.
  - Wall-clock time bins (day/hour/15m/5m): emphasizes bursts and pauses.

UX
- A simple toggle (Commit-time | Wall-clock) near the resolution controls.
- When wall-clock is on, bins that have 0 commits should still render (to show quiet periods).

Implementation Notes
- Requires reliable timestamp parsing for commits; define a single canonical timezone for binning (likely local or UTC, but must be explicit and consistent).
- Aggregation functions must be well-defined for all metrics (sum for counts, mean/median for rates); document each.
- Persist in URL state.

Acceptance Criteria
- Switching modes is instantaneous after first compute; charts and heat stripe update consistently.

Testing
- Unit tests for bin boundaries across DST and timezone offsets (use fixed ISO timestamps).
- E2E: toggle mode and verify bin count / labels change deterministically.

title: Binning: Wall-Clock Series Builder (Fill Empty Bins)
description:
Implement wall-clock binning:
- Inputs: commit timestamps (ISO), selected bin size (day/hour/15m/5m), timezone mode (UTC vs local).
- Output: dense bin array with explicit empty bins (0 commits) so quiet periods are visible.
- Aggregate metrics per bin with defined semantics (sum, mean, median).
- Ensure bin labeling is stable and readable.

title: Binning Toggle: UI + URL State + Chart Consistency
description:
Wire the binning mode toggle into the UX:
- Toggle near resolution controls; tooltip explains the difference.
- Ensure all charts (timeline, stacked buckets, donut, BOCPD/phase) read the same unified aggregation layer.
- URL state: mode=commit|wall + timezone mode (utc|local).
- Add a small "bin info" chip (bin size, bin count, empty bin count) for transparency.

title: Binning: Unit Tests (Timezone/DST Boundaries)
description:
Unit tests:
- Fixed ISO timestamps around DST transitions; assert correct bin assignment in UTC and in local mode.
- Empty bins: ensure they're present and labeled correctly.
- Aggregation semantics: sums/means/medians match reference calculations for a small dataset.

Diagnostics
- On failure: print timestamps, computed bin keys, and expected vs actual series.

title: Binning: E2E Tests (Toggle + Bin Count Assertions)
description:
E2E scenarios:
- Toggle commit-time -> wall-clock; assert chart x-axis labels change and bin count differs.
- Toggle timezone mode (if exposed): ensure labels update deterministically.
- URL round-trip: share link preserves mode and resolution.

Diagnostics
- Log mode, resolution, bin count, empty bin count, and first/last label.

title: Viz: Heat Stripe Under Dock (Bucket Density Over Time)
description:
Goal
- Add a compact "heat stripe" under the timeline dock that shows where changes are dense (and which buckets dominate) across the entire history. This makes it easy to spot bursts at a glance and jump there instantly.

UX
- The stripe spans the full width; each pixel/segment maps to a time bin; color encodes dominant bucket and intensity encodes total change mass.
- Hover/tap shows tooltip (time range, commit count, top buckets). Click jumps the main selection to the densest commit in that bin.

Implementation Notes
- Compute per-bin totals + per-bucket contributions; choose a deterministic "dominant bucket" rule with tie-breaking.
- Must stay readable in light mode; use subtle saturation, not neon.

Acceptance Criteria
- Stripe renders quickly; interaction is precise (no off-by-one bin selection).

Testing
- Unit tests for bin->pixel mapping and dominant-bucket selection.
- E2E tests: click stripe segment -> selection changes; tooltip content present.

title: Heat Stripe: Compute Density + Dominant Bucket per Bin
description:
Compute stripe data:
- For each bin, compute total change mass (configurable: lines/tokens/lev) and per-bucket contributions.
- Choose dominant bucket with deterministic tie-breaking (highest contribution, then lowest bucket id).
- Provide a mapping from bin -> "representative commit" (e.g., max delta commit) for jump behavior.
- Cache by dataset hash + mode (commit vs wall) + resolution + metric.

title: Heat Stripe: Dock UI Rendering + Tooltip + Click-to-Jump
description:
Render the stripe as a first-class dock element:
- Canvas or SVG implementation; must be crisp on high-DPI.
- Tooltip on hover/tap with time range, commit count, top buckets and intensity.
- Click selects representative commit and updates all panels/charts.
- Mobile: tap + hold shows tooltip; single tap jumps. Avoid accidental jumps while scrubbing.

title: Heat Stripe: Unit Tests (Bin Mapping + Dominance)
description:
Unit tests:
- Bin->pixel mapping: ensure first/last bins map to stripe bounds without gaps.
- Dominant bucket selection: tie-breaking is deterministic; intensity scaling is monotone.
- Representative commit selection per bin is stable.

Diagnostics
- Print bin summaries and selected mapping on failure.

title: Heat Stripe: E2E Tests (Tooltip + Jump)
description:
E2E scenarios:
- Hover/tap stripe -> tooltip appears with expected fields.
- Click stripe segment -> commit idx changes and timeline selection reflects it.
- Mobile: long-press shows tooltip; single tap jumps (verify no conflict with scrub gesture).

Diagnostics
- Log stripe segment index, inferred bin range, and selected representative commit hash.

title: Viz: Commit Clustering by Similarity (MinHash + Themes)
description:
Goal
- Group commits by similarity of their changes so users can see recurring "themes" (e.g., lots of scrivening, refactors, alien-math additions) and jump between similar edits quickly.

UX (Desktop)
- Cluster panel: list clusters with size + representative commit; clicking a cluster highlights its members on the timeline and filters the commit list.
- Optional "theme tags" derived from dominant buckets / keywords in diffs.

UX (Mobile)
- Cluster list in a sheet; selecting highlights and offers "next/prev in cluster" navigation.

Implementation Notes (Alien-Artifact Leaning)
- Use MinHash signatures over token shingles of the unified diff (or added-lines-only) to approximate Jaccard similarity efficiently.
- Run in WebWorker; cache signatures/clusters by dataset hash + params (shingle size, signature length, threshold).
- Keep clustering deterministic (stable ordering) so permalinks remain meaningful.

Acceptance Criteria
- Clusters are stable and useful; selecting a cluster makes it easy to explore similar commits in a few clicks.

Testing
- Unit tests on synthetic diffs with known overlap; assert clustering groups correctly.
- E2E: select cluster, verify timeline highlights and next/prev navigation works.

title: Clustering: Compute MinHash Signatures (Worker)
description:
Implement MinHash signature generation:
- Token shingling on diff text (configurable: full diff vs added-lines-only; shingle size k).
- Deterministic hash functions seeded from dataset hash so results are stable.
- Signature length parameter (e.g., 64/128).
- Store signatures compactly (Uint32Array) and persist in localStorage (base64 or JSON-safe encoding).
- Provide progress + cancellation.

title: Clustering: Deterministic Grouping (LSH/Threshold) + Theme Tags
description:
Cluster commits from MinHash signatures:
- Similarity estimate: signature agreement ratio -> approx Jaccard.
- Grouping strategy: deterministic threshold clustering (single-linkage) or LSH buckets; must be stable across runs.
- Theme tags: derive lightweight labels using dominant buckets + top keywords from added-lines (explainable).
- Output: clusters with stable IDs, representative commit (medoid), and member list.

title: Clustering: UI Panel + Timeline Highlight + Next/Prev Navigation
description:
Build the clustering UX:
- Cluster list with size, theme tags, and representative commit summary.
- Selecting a cluster highlights members on timeline/heat stripe and filters commit list; next/prev in cluster navigation buttons.
- URL state: selected cluster id and threshold params.
- Mobile: cluster list in sheet, with clear "next in cluster" CTA.

title: Clustering: Unit Tests (MinHash + Grouping Correctness)
description:
Unit tests:
- MinHash: synthetic sets with known Jaccard; assert estimator error within tolerance for chosen signature length.
- Determinism: same inputs produce same signatures/clusters (stable IDs).
- Grouping: synthetic diffs that should cluster together / apart; verify member sets.

Diagnostics
- Print signatures (first few hashes), similarity matrix slice, and resulting clusters on failure.

title: Clustering: E2E Tests (Select Cluster + Next/Prev)
description:
E2E scenarios:
- Open clustering panel; select top cluster -> timeline highlights appear and commit list filters.
- Use next/prev in cluster navigation; ensure selected commit remains within cluster membership.
- URL round-trip preserves selected cluster id + parameters.

Diagnostics
- Log selected cluster id, member count, and current commit hash after each navigation step.

title: Viz: Side-by-Side Markdown Panes (A vs B) + Synced Scroll
description:
Goal
- In A/B compare mode, add a side-by-side rendered markdown view (A on left, B on right) with synced scrolling and clear change cues. This is the fastest way to grok "what changed" while keeping the spec readable.

UX (Desktop)
- Two panes with a draggable divider; optional "sync scroll" toggle (on by default).
- Sync by headings/anchors when possible; fallback to proportional scroll.
- Hovering a heading path highlights the corresponding section in both panes.

UX (Mobile)
- Stacked/segmented control: A | B | Split (if landscape).
- Sync via "jump to same heading" rather than continuous scroll.

Implementation Notes
- Reuse reconstructed snapshots from A/B compare; avoid double recompute.
- Provide a robust mapping between A and B headings (by normalized heading text + path).

Acceptance Criteria
- Side-by-side mode is usable on large docs without jank.
- Heading jumps land at consistent corresponding sections.

Testing
- Unit tests for heading matching + scroll sync mapping.
- E2E: enable A/B, switch to side-by-side, scroll in A -> B follows; mobile A/B toggle works.

title: Side-by-Side: Two-Pane Layout + Divider + Sync Toggle
description:
Implement the core layout:
- Two scroll containers rendered concurrently; draggable divider; sync toggle; independent selection/highlighting.
- Preserve typography quality and code highlighting in both panes.
- Ensure virtualization isn't needed initially; keep perf acceptable via caching + worker.
- Add a "copy permalink" that includes A/B commit selection + view mode.

title: Side-by-Side: Heading Matching + Scroll Sync Algorithm
description:
Implement robust A<->B alignment:
- Normalize headings (case, punctuation) and use heading "path" (parent headings) to disambiguate duplicates.
- Scroll sync modes:
  - Anchor mode: keep nearest heading aligned between panes.
  - Proportional mode: fallback when anchor mapping missing.
- UX: show a small "linked" indicator when anchor sync is active; allow temporarily breaking sync while user scrolls quickly.

title: Side-by-Side: Mobile UX (A/B Tabs + Split in Landscape)
description:
Implement mobile-specific behavior:
- Default: segmented control A | B; preserve scroll position per pane.
- Landscape: allow split view; in portrait, offer "jump to same heading" CTA when switching panes.
- Ensure bottom dock does not overlap content; use safe-area insets.

title: Side-by-Side: Unit Tests (Heading Match + Scroll Sync)
description:
Unit tests:
- Heading matching: duplicates, renamed headings, moved sections; assert best-effort mapping and stable tie-breaking.
- Scroll sync: given outlines + scroll positions, assert target positions are monotone and do not oscillate.

Diagnostics
- Print mapped heading pairs and a few scroll sync steps on failure.

title: Side-by-Side: E2E Tests (Split View + Sync + Mobile Tabs)
description:
E2E scenarios:
- Desktop: enable A/B; open side-by-side; scroll left pane -> right follows; disable sync -> panes scroll independently.
- Mobile: switch A->B tab preserves scroll positions; "jump to same heading" works.

Diagnostics
- Log scrollTop values in both panes during sync and after mode toggles.

title: Viz: Inline Changed-Line Highlights in Rendered Markdown
description:
Goal
- Let users read the spec as a document *and still see what changed* inline: highlight added/changed lines/blocks directly in the rendered markdown pane (not only in Diff2Html).

UX (Desktop)
- Toggle: "Inline highlights". Added lines get a subtle left bar + background; modified blocks get a faint outline; hovering shows the bucket mix + Δ metrics for that block.
- Works with section summary and heading mini-map: changed headings show markers; clicking a marker scrolls to the next changed block.

UX (Mobile)
- Same toggle in sheet; changed blocks are navigable via "Next change" button (big tap target).

Implementation Notes
- Need a stable mapping from unified diff hunks to rendered DOM blocks. Likely approach: inject sentinel markers into the markdown before rendering (line/block wrappers), then post-process DOM to apply highlights and remove sentinels.
- Must not break code highlighting or typography.

Acceptance Criteria
- Inline highlights are accurate enough to be trusted; toggling is instant.

Testing
- Unit tests for hunk->block mapping and highlight application (synthetic markdown + diffs).
- E2E: toggle highlights, navigate next change, verify highlight present and stable across commit switches.

title: Inline Highlights: Hunk-to-DOM Mapping Strategy (Sentinels)
description:
Design + implement the mapping layer:
- Decide unit of highlighting: source line, paragraph block, list item, or code fence line.
- Approach: pre-process markdown to wrap candidate blocks/lines with sentinel markers that survive rendering, then locate those nodes in DOM to apply classes/styles.
- Ensure the approach handles headings, lists, code fences, tables (if supported), and inline code.
- Provide a "mapping debug" mode that can outline blocks and show their source ranges for troubleshooting.

title: Inline Highlights: Render Styles + Next/Prev Change Navigation
description:
Apply highlights and make them usable:
- Styles: subtle left bar + background for added blocks; outline for modified; optional bucket-color accent.
- Navigation: "Next change" / "Prev change" buttons; keyboard shortcuts on desktop; mobile big tap targets.
- Hover/tap on a highlighted block opens a tiny evidence popover (Δlines/tokens/lev + buckets).
- Must be stable across commit switches and when toggling between doc/diff views.

title: Inline Highlights: Unit Tests (Mapping + Highlight Application)
description:
Unit tests:
- Given synthetic markdown + diff hunks, assert the correct DOM blocks receive highlight classes.
- Duplicates: multiple identical lines; ensure highlights map to correct region deterministically.
- Code blocks: ensure syntax highlighting remains intact and highlights don't break code formatting.

Diagnostics
- On failure: dump the intermediate sentinel-marked markdown and a simplified DOM tree with highlighted nodes.

title: Inline Highlights: E2E Tests (Toggle + Next Change + Stability)
description:
E2E scenarios:
- Toggle inline highlights on; verify at least one highlighted block exists for a known commit with changes.
- Use next/prev change navigation; assert scroll position changes and highlight remains visible.
- Switch commit; highlights refresh correctly; no stale highlights remain.

Diagnostics
- Log commit idx/hash, highlight count, and current highlighted block id/path after each step.

title: Viz: Heading Mini-Map + Changed-Section Highlighting
description: Add a left-side (desktop) / slide-over (mobile) heading mini-map generated from the rendered markdown, with per-commit indicators for which headings changed. Clicking a heading scrolls the doc pane; diff view can auto-scroll to first change under that heading.

title: Viz: Shareable Permalinks (URL State) + Copy Link
description: Encode visualization state in the URL (commit idx, tab, resolution, metric, bucket filters). Add a Copy Link button. Deep links should load without needing any server logic.

title: Viz: Story Mode (Curated Milestones + Autoplay)
description: Add an optional narrative layer: curated milestones (hand-picked commits) with short annotations and an autoplay scrubber. Desktop: right-side timeline card; Mobile: full-screen swipeable cards.

title: Viz: Performance Pass (Worker Metrics + Caching)
description: Move heavy work (patch application for far jumps, Levenshtein precompute) into a WebWorker; cache reconstructed snapshots/metrics in-memory + localStorage keyed by dataset hash. Keep initial load fast.

title: Viz: Dataset Tooling (Regen + Validate)
description: Add a small, safe regeneration + validation tool for spec_evolution_data_v1.json.gz (append new commits, assert patches apply cleanly, assert commit counts match git). Prefer a one-shot CLI (Rust or Python) with zero repo-wide rewrites.

title: Viz: Playback Mode (Play/Pause + Speed Control + Loop)
description:
Goal
- Add a true playback mode that automatically advances commits like a video scrubber (play/pause/step), with speed control and optional loop. This should feel extremely smooth on mobile and enable passive exploration.

UX (Desktop)
- Play/pause, step back/forward, speed (0.25x..8x), loop toggle in the bottom dock.
- While playing, charts and doc panes stay responsive; no layout jank.

UX (Mobile)
- Thumb-zone controls: big play/pause + step; speed via compact sheet slider; haptics optional (if available).
- Autopause on heavy interactions (manual scrub, text selection, opening panels).

Implementation Notes
- Deterministic state machine (playing/paused/seeking) with requestAnimationFrame or setInterval + drift correction; use document visibility API to pause in background.
- Respect prefers-reduced-motion: default to paused and lower update rate.
- Persist playback state via URL state (depends on permalinks).

Acceptance Criteria
- Can play from any commit; index advances monotonically at chosen rate; pause freezes index exactly.
- Manual scrub interrupts playback safely and predictably.
- No console errors; no noticeable lag on mid-range mobile.

Testing
- Unit tests for scheduler drift correction + state transitions.
- E2E (Playwright) for desktop + mobile: start play, observe commit index change, pause, scrub, resume; capture console + timing logs.

title: Playback: Core Scheduler + State Machine
description:
Implement a deterministic playback controller:
- State machine: paused | playing | seeking (manual scrub) with clear transitions.
- Drift correction (don't accumulate setInterval drift); clamp index at ends; loop option.
- Document visibility: pause when hidden; resume optionally.
- Hooks: onTick(commitIndex) -> render; onManualScrub -> cancel playback safely.

Deliverables
- Small, testable pure functions for time->commit index mapping and transition logic (used by unit tests).

title: Playback: Dock UI + Mobile Controls
description:
Wire playback controls into the UI:
- Bottom dock: play/pause, step, speed slider, loop toggle, and a "playing" indicator that doesn't feel noisy.
- Mobile: larger tap targets + optional speed control inside the existing bottom sheet.
- A11y: keyboard shortcuts for play/pause and step; ARIA labels; respects prefers-reduced-motion (no autoplay).
- Interaction rules: any manual scrub immediately pauses; changing tab (diff/doc/metrics) should not break playback.

title: Playback: Unit Tests (Scheduler + State Transitions)
description:
Add comprehensive unit tests with detailed logging for the playback controller.

Scope
- State transition table coverage (paused<->playing<->seeking).
- Drift correction: simulate wall-clock drift and assert expected index sequence.
- Loop/clamp behavior at bounds.
- Reduced-motion behavior: default paused; no autoplay.

Constraints
- Prefer Node built-in test runner (node:test) or the lightest possible harness (avoid adding a package manager).
- Tests should log scenario name, seed (if any), timing parameters, and resulting index sequence for fast debugging.

title: Playback: E2E Tests (Playwright Desktop + Mobile)
description:
Add E2E coverage for playback in a real browser (Playwright) with strong diagnostics.

Scenarios
- Desktop viewport: open page, wait for dataset load, press play, assert commit index advances; pause; step; scrub; resume.
- Mobile viewport: same scenarios; verify tap targets; ensure dock/sheet controls remain usable.

Logging
- Capture console logs + page errors; emit structured step logs with timestamps and current commit hash/idx.
- On failure: screenshot + HTML dump + console tail.

Acceptance Criteria
- Tests pass reliably (no flaky timing). Use explicit waits tied to UI state (not arbitrary sleeps).

title: Viz: Section-Level Diff Summary (Per-Heading Metrics)
description:
Goal
- Provide a section-level summary of what changed for the current commit (and for A/B compares): per-heading counts for lines/tokens/lev + dominant buckets, so users can jump directly to the interesting parts.

UX (Desktop)
- New panel: a sortable table (Heading | Δlines | Δtokens | Δlev | top buckets) + tiny sparklines.
- Clicking a row scrolls the doc pane; optional "focus mode" that temporarily collapses other UI to keep attention on the section.

UX (Mobile)
- Sheet-first: compact list with clear Δ badges; tapping jumps + highlights that section briefly.

Implementation Notes
- Parse rendered markdown headings into a stable outline (id anchors).
- Map diff hunks to headings by nearest preceding heading boundary in the *rendered* doc.
- Cache per-commit section summaries; compute incrementally to avoid O(N^2).

Acceptance Criteria
- For any commit, user can see a list of headings with meaningful "what changed" numbers and jump accurately.
- Sorting and filtering are fast.

Testing
- Unit tests for heading extraction and hunk->heading mapping (synthetic docs/diffs).
- E2E tests: click top changed section -> scrolls and highlights; works on mobile.

title: Section Summary: Heading Outline Extraction + Stable Anchors
description:
Implement a robust heading outline extractor:
- Source of truth: rendered markdown headings (not raw markdown) so IDs match scroll targets.
- Generate stable anchor IDs and store (heading text, level, element id, offsetTop) for the current snapshot.
- Handle duplicate headings (disambiguate IDs deterministically).
- Expose a query API: getOutline(commitIdx) -> outline[] used by mini-map + section summary.

title: Section Summary: Attribute Diff Hunks to Headings + Metrics
description:
Compute per-heading change metrics for each commit:
- Parse unified diff hunks; attribute each added/removed line to the nearest preceding heading boundary in the rendered snapshot.
- Metrics per heading: Δlines (add/del), Δtokens (approx), Δlev (from WASM), and bucket contributions (if classification exists).
- Caching: memoize per-commit summaries keyed by dataset hash + commit idx + resolution.
- Performance: incremental compute; avoid rebuilding entire outline each time.

title: Section Summary: UI Panel + Jump/Highlight Interactions
description:
Build the UX for section-level summaries:
- Desktop: sortable table + filters + tiny sparklines; click row scrolls doc to heading and briefly highlights it (non-jarring animation).
- Mobile: bottom-sheet list with large tap targets and a "back to list" affordance.
- Integrate with existing heading mini-map: shared outline + consistent highlighting.
- Ensure interaction works in both single-commit view and A/B compare mode.

title: Section Summary: Unit Tests (Outline + Hunk Attribution)
description:
Unit tests with strong diagnostics:
- Heading extraction: duplicates, weird punctuation, deep nesting, empty headings.
- Hunk attribution: synthetic docs + diffs; assert correct section attribution and metric sums.
- Performance sanity: ensure attribution is near-linear in diff size for typical cases.

Logging
- Each test logs input outline + diff summary and the resulting per-section metrics on failure.

title: Section Summary: E2E Tests (Jump to Section + Mobile Sheet)
description:
E2E coverage:
- Desktop: open section summary, sort by Δlev, click top row -> doc scrolls to correct heading; highlight appears then fades.
- Mobile: open sheet, tap section -> jumps; back to list works; no dock overlap.

Diagnostics
- Log selected heading id/text, scrollTop before/after, and whether highlight element is present.

title: Viz: Search Across History (First-Introduced + Most-Edited)
description:
Goal
- Add a powerful search experience across the entire spec evolution: find text/sections across commits, answer "when was this introduced?", and identify the most-edited sections over time.

UX (Desktop)
- Global search (Cmd/Ctrl+K): type query, see ranked results grouped by (Commit) and (Section).
- Quick actions: jump to commit, open diff, pin as a "reference".

UX (Mobile)
- Search button in header; full-screen search sheet with large results and 1-tap jump.

Implementation Notes
- Build an offline-friendly index (no GitHub API): tokenization + inverted index over (commit subject, diff patch text, headings).
- Compute/refresh in a worker; persist in localStorage keyed by dataset hash.
- Provide query modes: exact phrase, token contains, and "first-introduced" (earliest commit where token appears in added lines).

Acceptance Criteria
- Query latency feels instant after index build; initial build shows progress and can be canceled.
- Jump from a search result lands at the right commit + section and highlights the match.

Testing
- Unit tests for tokenization/index correctness (including tricky punctuation).
- E2E tests: search on desktop/mobile, jump to result, verify highlight and correct commit selection.

title: Spec: TxnSlot claiming_timestamp stale during CLEANING takeover
description: In §5.6.2 cleanup_orphaned_slots, a cleaner CASes txn_id -> TXN_ID_CLEANING and then stores claiming_timestamp=now. There is a window where another cleaner can observe txn_id==TXN_ID_CLEANING while claiming_timestamp still contains a stale value from the previous owner (Phase 1 claim time), causing spurious 'stuck CLEANING' takeover. Proposed fix: after Phase 3 publish CAS succeeds (TXN_ID_CLAIMING -> real_txn_id), clear claiming_timestamp to 0 (Release). This makes a future CLEANING transition start from 0, so concurrent cleaners seed a fresh timestamp via CAS(0->now) rather than treating stale timestamps as stuck.
close_reason: Completed in spec: TxnSlot Phase 3 publish clears claiming_timestamp to 0 (Release); cleanup_orphaned_slots seeds claiming_timestamp via CAS(0->now) for CLAIMING/CLEANING so stale timestamps cannot trigger spurious stuck-CLEANING takeover.
